text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new apathy
record Connecticut casual apathy is a
Connecticut based producer and rapper
whose exploits I have been following for
years now back when I was in college I
used to listen to a rap group he was
affiliated with heavily affiliated with
the demigods I fell out of tune with his
new output for a while but I ended
catching up back with him again once he
started dropping newer records like
honky Kong in my opinion one of the
better rap albums of 2011 and since then
he has been pretty busy he dropped a
pretty huge and lengthy fire walk with
me mixtape he reassembled the demigods
and they dropped a new record and he has
tons of ruthless verses all over the new
army of Pharos album this is a new
prolific revitalization for apathy scre
ear but there has been no project he's
been involved with that I have been more
excited for than his next commercial
release right here now going into this
thing I did have my hesitations he did
drop a video single before this album
came out for the song grand leveler the
last track off of this LP the video is
loaded with Freemason imagery and apathy
is embrace of this long-running
fraternity comes through in the visuals
of the video more than it does the
actual lyrics of the song either way
it's not really a good look for someone
who's a rapper I mean all you have to do
is show some of these hip-hop fans a
triangle all is that Loompa natty are
you loompa daddy is human Addie is that
way you're popular I thought I knew you
this whole time but it just turns out
off would you shut up idiot ah but
outside of any extracurricular
activities apathy may be indulging in
outside of his hip-hop career I didn't
really go into this record with any
expectations other than what I already
know of apathy is artistic output he's a
rapper that really values storytelling
going into a song with a message or a
concept in mind much of the time he has
a flow and a delivery that is straight
out of the world
90s boom bap hip-hop he is definitely a
student of guys like biggie wu-tang NAS
organized confusion and a lot of his
production sensibilities come from the
same era of hip-hop though I do think on
this new record of his he has made some
attempts at sort of modernizing like
with the song back in New England a
grimy ass banger of a track the bass is
heavy they're all these wailing quirky
kind of weird guitar leads in the left
channel squawking out it's a song that's
mean muggin it's intimidating like a 90s
boom bap track but there's something
kind of goofy and playful about it too
then there's the song grass ain't
greener we're apathy is bringing this
really speedy flow over very relaxed
atmospheric beat these kinds of serene
instrumentals are really in vogue right
now in hip hop and I think he does it
justice especially with the really
pretty singsong chorus on this thing
then production wives apathy also makes
some really ballsy sample choices like
on the track Martha Moxley rest in peace
where he samples very obviously and very
blatantly George Michaels Careless
Whisper the sax rip that opens up the
track and even though it's very clear
where the saxophone is coming from as
soon as the song starts it's still such
a blissful instrumental it just works so
well so well that it just makes me think
how is this not happened already
but sometimes the obvious samples on
this record do work against apathy in a
sense like on the opening track here
the title track where he is sampling
Anthony Kiedis vocals from the Red Hot
Chili Peppers song under the bridge
namely from the chorus of the song and
even though I'm not against sampling
this vocal because the song is very
obvious everybody knows this song I
guess I'm more against how untreated the
vocal on this track feels it just makes
it more difficult to imagine this vocal
with another groove with another context
I think my least favorite instrumental
on the entire record has to be the one
on underground chick where there's this
really blatant Smashing Pumpkins sample
it's got a bit of a trap flavor with
these incessant hi-hats twittering away
throughout the track and even though I
think it was really ambitious for
to try to chop this song up in this way
it is one of the more creative chops of
any of the samples throughout this
entire LP I guess it's how the beat
comes together with apathy rapping on
this song that really ends up turning me
off beyond these tracks the
instrumentals are pretty straightforward
they're smooth they're efficient they're
good at setting the tone of these tracks
like the shimmering guitar chords and
lines all over the track don't give up
the ship
the aged dusty pianos on curse of the
Kennedys and Jack Ruby fitting the tone
of the culture being talked about in
these songs and then I guess the really
ritzy horns and strings on the song
money makes the world go round fits the
tone and the subject matter of that
track to the production doesn't blow my
mind most of the time it just kind of
gets the job done it's lyrically and
conceptually where I really think this
album impresses and kind of comes
together being somebody from Connecticut
I came into this record expecting some
kind of connecticut-based content given
the title of it and apathy didn't really
disappoint we have tracks on this record
that hilariously and ironically embrace
Connecticut and New England based
stereotypes like on the song back in New
England where the hook is so stone-faced
and just mentioning things like Ray Bans
seersucker boat shoes Yacht Club j.crew
seafood not hip hop things but the track
appears way more hard as nails on the
verses especially with the Chris
Webber's the Chris Webb II verse on this
thing was killer and there are moments
on this record as well where he exposes
a bit of dark underbelly and some
debauchery like again on the opening the
title track of this thing where he is
not only talking about the culture of
his past his personal past but also
Willimantic where he grew up and then
there are songs on here that address the
the greater culture of New England in
general songs like curse of the Kennedys
I mean if you're going to talk about New
England royalty the Kennedy family is
pretty much it then there's the song
Martha Moxley rest in peace if you're
from Connecticut and my age or older you
probably have very vivid memories of the
Michael Skakel case and there are other
tracks on this LP that while they may
not be directly Connecticut related or
New England
they were late to these tracks like Jack
Ruby a song that essentially makes a
huge reference to the guy who shot Lee
Harvey Oswald who is allegedly the
assassinator of John F Kennedy the song
grass is greener topically links right
into the song money makes the world go
round the song underground chick in a
way links into the song beef and over
however there are some tracks on
this thing that I think sound really
weak when they're by themselves like the
song locals-only good verse from apathy
but not one of the more focused tracks
topically on this entire LP and not one
of the better guest verses on here
either either either either either
either either it not only instrumentally
but lyrically - I think underground
chick continues to rank as my least
favorite song it's really one of the
shorter and to me one of the more not
cohesive tracks on this entire LP
especially as apathy just slips into
this what about this girl didn't high
and listening to his she's a little
underground chick and immediately after
this the song just sort of ends
meanwhile the Smashing Pumpkins sample
that's already sort of trying my
patience is just going on and on and on
and on in the background and not really
fitting the beat change at this point in
the track it's just not one of the well
crafted songs off this record I think
and ambitious experiment but not one of
my favorite tracks overall I think this
is one of app these most solid projects
today I think it's maybe a shade more
enjoyable than his last full-length
record but even this LP has its handful
of songs that I either don't care for or
I think pale in comparison to others
just like that album did I'm feeling of
strong 7 to a light 8 on this thing
transition if you've given this record
to listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it apathy Connecticut casual
forever
